stem: The nurse is using a shared computer workstation in a busy clinical area. Which actions demonstrate adherence to 2026 digital security and patient privacy standards? Select all that apply.

options.text: Positioning the monitor so that it is not visible to the public or visitors.
Sharing a unique login password with a colleague during a code blue emergency.
Reporting any observed 'tailgating' (unauthorized persons following staff into secure areas) to security.
Utilizing a privacy screen filter on all mobile charting devices.
Logging off the electronic health record (EHR) immediately after every use.
Closing the browser tab instead of selecting 'Log Out' to save time.

rationale.correct: Workstation security is a major focus of 2026 HIPAA updates. (A) Manual log-off is required to prevent unauthorized access if automatic timers fail. This prevents unauthorized individuals from accessing patient data, ensuring confidentiality and compliance with HIPAA regulations. (B) Physical positioning prevents 'shoulder surfing' by the public. This safeguards sensitive patient information from being viewed by unauthorized individuals in the vicinity. (D) Privacy filters are mandatory for mobile devices that may be used in public view. These filters restrict the viewing angle, preventing unauthorized individuals from seeing the screen's content. (F) Security awareness includes reporting physical breaches (tailgating) that could lead to unauthorized system access. This helps maintain the physical security of the facility and prevents unauthorized access to computer systems.
rationale.incorrect: (C) Passwords must *never* be shared, even in emergencies; most systems have 'emergency access' or 'break glass' protocols that do not require password sharing. Sharing passwords compromises security and accountability, violating HIPAA regulations. (E) Closing a browser tab does not always terminate the session; always use the formal 'Log Out' or 'Sign Out' command. Failing to log out properly leaves the system vulnerable to unauthorized access, potentially leading to data breaches.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: "Logging off the electronic health record (EHR) immediately after every use." is correct because it prevents unauthorized access to patient information and maintains confidentiality.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: "Positioning the monitor so that it is not visible to the public or visitors." is correct because it prevents unauthorized viewing of patient information.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: "Sharing a unique login password with a colleague during a code blue emergency." is incorrect because it violates security protocols and compromises patient privacy. Emergency access protocols should be used instead.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: "Utilizing a privacy screen filter on all mobile charting devices." is correct because it prevents unauthorized viewing of patient information on mobile devices.

answerBreakdown.label: E
answerBreakdown.content: "Closing the browser tab instead of selecting 'Log Out' to save time." is incorrect because it may not fully terminate the session, leaving the system vulnerable to unauthorized access.

answerBreakdown.label: F
answerBreakdown.content: "Reporting any observed 'tailgating' (unauthorized persons following staff into secure areas) to security." is correct because it helps prevent unauthorized physical access to secure areas and systems.

clinicalPearls: Automatic log-offs are a backup, not a primary security measure. Always log off manually.
Never share your password, even in an emergency. Use emergency access protocols.
Be aware of your surroundings and prevent 'shoulder surfing' by positioning monitors appropriately.
Report any suspicious activity or security breaches immediately.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: NCLEX almost never allows a security or safety breach 'because it was an emergency.' Professional standards (like password privacy) are absolute.

mnemonic.title: S-L-O-W
mnemonic.expansion: Screen privacy, Log off, Only your password, Watch for intruders.

reviewUnits.heading: Cybersecurity in Healthcare
reviewUnits.body: Nurses are the front line against data breaches. Human error (like failing to log off) is the leading cause of healthcare data exposure.

itemContext.sbar:
Situation: 0900: A nurse is using a shared computer workstation in a busy clinical area.
Background: Maintaining digital security and patient privacy is crucial in healthcare settings to comply with HIPAA and prevent data breaches. Shared workstations are vulnerable points.
Assessment: The nurse needs to identify actions that adhere to 2026 digital security and patient privacy standards. Current observations indicate potential risks due to the shared workstation environment.
Recommendation: The nurse should immediately log off after each use, position monitors to prevent unauthorized viewing, utilize privacy screens on mobile devices, and promptly report any security breaches or suspicious activities, such as tailgating, to security personnel.
